column2: §Y*§! Can prepare campaigns to §YReclaim Mexico§!, if §YNon-Cristero§! and inside the de jure Empire of Mexico.

The once-glorious Mexican Empire has been shattered: Left open to rebellion in the North due to constant incursions by the Californians, the imperial army was shattered by Luis "la Cucaracha" at the watershed Battle of Ojinaga. That loss allowed the Plan of Ixcateopan — a coalition of freedom-minded indigenous leaders in the South to enact their wish for dissolution of the Empire and self-rule. Meanwhile, the Cristero lords of the Bajío now whisper of a new Cristiada, to reclaim their home in the name of Cristo Rey. In the Southeast, the nascent Kingdom of Yucatán seems poised to usurp Mexico's position as the dominant power, but turmoil within and the Caribbean Empire without, stand in its way.

The once-glorious Mexican Empire has been shattered: Left open to rebellion in the North due to constant incursions by the Californians, the imperial army was shattered by Luis "la Cucaracha" at the watershed Battle of Ojinaga. That loss allowed the Plan of Ixcateopan — a coalition of freedom-minded indigenous leaders in the South to enact their wish for dissolution of the Empire and self-rule. Meanwhile, the Cristero lords of the Bajío now whisper of a new Cristiada, to reclaim their home in the name of Cristo Rey. In the Southeast, the nascent Kingdom of Yucatán seems poised to usurp Mexico's position as the dominant power, but turmoil within and the Caribbean Empire without, stand in its way.

Once allies in the Plan de Ixcateopan that shattered the Mexican Empire, the Zapotecas and Mixtecas quickly found themselves at odds with each other over territorial disputes. After a brief conflict between the two peoples, the Zapoteca princess Pinopiaa and her sister, Nadxieelii, were offered offered up by their father as hostages to the Mixtecas as a pledge of peace. However, with the death of the Zapoteca king and no male heir, Pinopiaa now must return to Oaxaca to be queen of her people. But will her love and marriage to a Mixteca prince allow her to free her sister from captivity, or will it doom her bloodline and her people to subjugation by the Mixtecas?

The house of Iturbide descends from Julián "el Grande", the legendary Jefe Máximo of Mexico that was able to reclaim most of the lost lands of the empire, but the family has fallen on hard times by the year 2666. The current head of the Iturbides, Wenceslao I, rules over a vestigial state barely worthy of the name Mexico. Surrounded by heathens, rival caudillos, and squabbling principalities, it seems unlikely that the rulers of Mexico will ever be able to regain their former glory. Will Wenceslao defy the odds and reverse his dynasty's recent fortune, or is the empire doomed to be swallowed by the tides of history like its contemperaries from days long forgotten?

When he was a young man, King Luis was a member of the Dorados, the legendary company of vaqueros and cowboys that served as the empires most effective — and unruly — task force. While in the service, he found salvation in the holy Atom and convinced many of his compatriots and fellow disciples to embark on a holy conquest of Mexico. At the battle of El Paso, Luis "la Cucaracha" destroyed the Imperial Army and carved out a realm for himself south of the Rio Grande. However, King Louis is no longer a young man — he is now 80 years old, and it seems that he will soon become one with the Atom. Although his son Jesús seems like a worthy successor, some still fear that without Luis to guide it, this new kingdom is doomed to fall as quickly as it emerged.

column1: #these are for accent marks and getting rid of overuse of de in Spanish surnames

column2: King Gastón of las Bajas is one of the few truly great rulers left in California. Although his personal habits leave something to be desired, nobody can deny that Gastón is one of the strongest and most skilled warriors in all of California. As the Empire of California continues its slow decline, Gastón finds himself in a unique position. Will Gaston be content with his current title, or will he shed his hedonism and use his unique gifts to aim for something... greater?

The cult of "el Niño Fidencio" follows a pantheon of quasi-deities derived from Catholic saints and heroes of the past, who are ultimately subservient to God but powerful in their own right. These entities are called upon for guidance and can be communed with through ritualistic means, but the most faithful heirs to "el Niñito" can allow themselves to become possessed by the saints to perform miracles and act as a conduit to allow the divine to directly influence the world.
§Y*§!Homosexual Fidencistas are allowed to marry other homosexual characters.\n§Y*§! Kings and emperors are expected to become "Cajitas" — Those who play host to the most revered spirits.

The "Missionaries of the Sacred Heart" combine traditions of the old Catholic church with an eagerness to incorporate local traditions and saints into the faith — even going as far as to elevate the angel of death to a quasi-deity. While this adaptability has allowed the religion to quickly take root in the religious chaos of Mexico, it has caused great divergence from the other Catholic splinter churches who now regard the faithful as polytheistic heathens.

§Y*§!Homosexual followers of La Santa Muerte are allowed to marry other homosexual characters. \n§Y*§! May experience visions of the Blessed Virgin called Marian Apparitions.\n§Y*§! La Santa Muerte demands respect for the dead and can be called on to help exact revenge.

The term Patria Grande, or Great Fatherland, is to its followers both a political ideal and a divine mandate of Dios. The adherents of the faith worship both the Holy Trinity and the hero-saints of the past who liberated and ruled the original Patria Grande, bringing what they consider a golden age. As a result the faithful aspire to see the legendary homeland unified once more. Their pantheon is made up of "próceres", divinities originating from the syncretism between the founders of Gran Colombia and several Catholic saints.
§Y*§! Patria Grande rulers can choose from one of three patron próceres, which impacts their options for succession.

The Prelature of Cristo Rey, Christ the king, was organized to hold the splintering Church in Mexico together in the face of heathenry. In time, the Prelature filled the void of a strong church leadership and assumed de-facto control of the ordinal functions of the Catholic Church of Mexico, declaring the other Catholic successor churches heretical farces. In the absence of what they see as a legitimate pope, the Cristeros have elevated their Prelado, or Prelate, to a position of steward of the church who assumes many of the sacred duties of the Pope.

§Y*§!Can prepare campaigns known as §YCristiadas§! against heathen religions within the de jure borders of the Empire of Mexico \n§Y*§! May experience visions of the Blessed Virgin called Marian Apparitions.\n§Y*§! May expend Piety to raise units of zealots during a war.

The Reformista faith has its origins in the idea that belief should not be controlled by a strict Church. Beneméritos of old have tried to bring these ideals to fruition, the latest being Benemérito José Elías, who liberalized the structure of belief, opening up the Church to popular devotions without restriction. The fate of people's souls is far too important to be decided by priests who know not their flock. Thus, it is imperative that the Church have a protector who knows the needs of its people well and is not distracted by lofty pursuits and rigid hierarchies. By God and Liberty, the Benemérito is the one who must lead as only through respecting the various beliefs of others, can there be peace.

Purificadores — Purifiers — are a loosely organized christian doctrine that has its roots in pentecostal missions established not long before the Event. They believe that the faith's arrival to Central America was the first seal of the Apocalypse being broken. Such is their eschatology, that they identify even their fellow Christians as the prophesied Whore of Babylon. Their fundamentalist views on the Bible make them reject all other faiths as idolatrous and satanic, and they are willing to make them see their error, by force if needed — For those who are taken into the family of God, shall be gifted.

Penitentes — Penitents — are so called because they believe that after the Event, the world was given a second chance at redemption — which must be atoned for with sorrowful and extenuant rituals that were once reserved for the holiest of weeks — as now every week must be Holy. The Penance that must be performed can be as little as praying, face to the floor, to being honored pallbearers of enormous images from the Passion of Christ. These traditions make them a disciplined people, capable of doing anything for their brothers in sacrifice.

Unitas Fratrum, or "Unity of the Brethren", is a Christian church whose message of reformation and unity quickly took root in Central America in the wake of the Event. The Unitas Fratrum, who owes its origin in Central America to ancient missions in La Moskitia, cherishes its unity as a valuable treasure entrusted to it by the Lord as it represents the oneness of all humankind in the Body of Christ. Therefore the ecumenical movement is of its very lifeblood — permitting the incorporation of many traditions and structures with its middle-ground theology under the guidance of the Church. For a millennia, it has pointed towards the unity of the scattered children of God that they may become one in their Lord.

Navigants believe those who are brave, those who are patient, are blessed by the sea. Legends warn of the dangers and curses beneath the rolling waves, our Saviour and Provider calls us to walk over the waters to his grace so he may gift us our daily Manna of the Sea.
§Y*§!Navegantes are allowed to forcefully baptize prisoners.\n§Y*§! Navegantes may sacrifice animals to Ichtys.

Mictlanteca is a continuation of ancient indigenous traditions and maintains that the keeper of the underworld had mercy after the complete destruction of Humanity in the previous cycle and guided them back to the land of the living. According to the Mictlantecos, the destruction of the last cycle was the result of the neglect and abandonment of sacrifice to spiritual entities known as dueños" — the true "owners" of the land who dwell in the hills, springs, caves, and other natural features that dot the landscape. The Mictlantecos believe that the equilibrium of life requires death and that a regular practice of the ancient sacrifices and rituals is necessary to maintain the balance of the world.
§Y*§! May go on vision quests with the aid of sacramental herbs.\n§Y*§! Mictlantecos may sacrifice animals to the Dueños.

The Soltaic Church of the Sol Invicto believes that at the end of the second era, the Serpent covered the world in darkness and chaos. To combat this evil, God the Sun clothed his wife, the Moon, in his fiery raiment and gave life to a son who would be sent to bring light back to the world. Like the great sacrifice of the Messiah of the second era, this Messiah, the first Son of the Sun, devoted his life to creating the Seven Seals and rituals that trap the Serpent in the underworld and keep the darkness at bay. As successor of this final Messiah, the Gran Hijo del Sol and his Guardians must keep ever viligant and maintain the seals through proper worship of God the Sun - the Sol Invicto - lest the Serpent return.
§Y*§! The Gran Hijo del Sol is elected using the same mechanics as the Pope.

The history of the Latter Day Saints in Central America began not long before the Event, as Elder missionaries came to preach the message of Prophet Joseph Smith to the Lamanites. They firmly believe that the events described in the Book of Mormon happened in Central America, mixing the veneration of ancestors and exalted figures who were mistaken as gods in the past. An ancient prophecy holds that the Lamanites 'shall blossom as a rose', and they are keen to see its fulfillment.

Furiegi — the Prayers — are the ancestral beliefs of the Garifuna, syncretized with Mormon theology introduced by missionary work. Furiegi differs from the Lamanite Church in structure and practice, with a priority on traditional matriarchal authority, and a purely ritual use of alcohol.

Steadfastly refusing to recognize the religious authorities in Mexico, St. Louis, or Quebec as legitimate leaders of Catholicism, the Catholic Bishops in the Caribbean began administering their respective dioceses or "Insula" with their own unique rites. While the teachings of Caribbean Catholic priests generally stay within mainstream Catholicism, foreign Christians often opine that many of the "African Saints" venerated by individual Insular Catholics are suspiciously similar to the entities venerated in Voodoo and Santeria

Wormwoodism began as a movement within Insular Catholicism, named after Bishop Wormwood of Andros. Bishop Wormwood strongly condemned the practices of the African-rooted syncretic religions of the Caribbean, condemning especially those who engaged in those practices while professing Catholicism. He also accused the Popes in St. Louis of forging a false apostolic succession from whole cloth, characterizing them as wolves in sheep's clothing. After the conquest of the Caribbean by Portia Bustamante, Wormwoodists turned on the Insular clergy, claiming that their inaction with regards to the growing influence of the Afro-syncretists and the St. Louis Papacy means that the Insular Clergy must be violently overthrown and replaced.
The Jefe Supremo of the Seven Seals is the Jefe next in line to become the Gran Hijo del Sol
This Guardian is probably next in line for an Jefatura when one becomes available.
Of all the Guardians in my realm, this one is the likeliest to get called as a Jefe of the Seven Seals.

When the Deluge severed contact between the New World and Rome, Catholicism entered an age of uncertainty. That led some to retreat into tradition, particularly the liturgy of the church. Latinates see Ecclesiastical Latin as a divine language with the abilities such as curing illnesses, calming madness, and driving out demons. Opinion differs among Latinates on whether Latin is connected to the Holy Spirit, the original Adamic language, or the word of God himself. The Latinates retain their own priesthood and continue to practice the Tridentine Mass while praying for the return of the Pontifex Maximus, who they believe will reemerge before the Second Coming.

With a sword in hand and faith in his heart, Benemérito Wenceslao el Tizón led the Empire of Mexico to its apex, with the hand of Blessed Virgin guiding his every action. After his decisive battle with Maximiliano II Jaurégui near Toluca he legitimized the Sagrado Corazón Faith.
This former Captain General of Yucatán shocked Mexico by suddenly converting to Neomayanism and joining the plan to declare independence from the Mexican Empire.
The venerable blood of the Jacaranda family whose tireless devotion to The Republic, Senate and People of México revitilised through multiple generations the ancient Empire of México City.
The Scourge of Mexico, Luis "la Cucaracha" de Armas was a former Dorado who turned on the Mexican Benemérito and carved a realm of his own, Sierra Madre.

Like the prophets and great teachers of the faith before [Root.GetFirstName] has fulfilled the ancient prophecies and legends and restored the Lamanites into righteousness with God founding a new holy bloodline.
Like the prophets and great teachers of the faith before [Root.GetFirstName] has fulfilled tghteousness with God founding a newbloodline.
This blood once ruled Ancient Mexico as an Empire in which the Sun never set. It is now restored to glory by victorious Justo Armas.
This bishop is probably next in line for an Apostleship when one becomes available.
Of all the bishops in my realm, this one is the likeliest to get called as an Apóstol.

With a score of $SCORE$ you$FAILED$ beat House Nájera, Jefes Máximos of Mexico. Julián accomplished something few ever have, restoring most of the borders of a pre-Event nation and gaining recognition as a true continuation of that ancient land. For a time, they nearly ruled the entirety of Old Mexican territory. Nearly all of this was lost over the centuries, but they maintained control of the ancient capital, and stubbornly keep the memory of Mexico alive.

With a score of $SCORE$ you$FAILED$ beat House Nájera , Jefes Máximos of Mexico. Julián accomplished something few ever have, restoring most of the borders of a pre-Event nation and gaining recognition as a true continuation of that ancient land. For a time, they nearly ruled the entirety of Old Mexican territory. Nearly all of this was lost over the centuries, but they maintained control of the ancient capital, and stubbornly keep the memory of Mexico alive.

It is finally done our goal prophesied so long ago by the founder of the Latter Day Saints has come to pass and we have carved out a mighty nation for the Lamanite people and restored our selves in the sight of the Godhead formalizing our faith from a gathering of the dissipated to a great church filled with might temples and diligent missionaries to continue to spread the faith to all of the peoples of America.
We have bloomed like a rose!

Interesting news has come out of the lands of Central America. With a people claiming to be an ancient people called the lamanites supposedly to have restored themselves in the eyes of God and have been rewarded with a mighty empire of their own. Even now tales of their great temple cities spread like wildfire throughout the lands of the south and their missionaries travel far and wide wishing to bring under their banner. Only time will tell if this empire will truly bloom like a rose or walk into obscurity like so many others.
Finally our destiny has been fulfilled.
Finally our Lamanite brothers have fulfilled their destiny.
On the final day many will cry 'Lord Lord have we not prophesied in your name' we shall see if these heretics shall also be cast into the fire.
More strange men with strange robes we shall prove our gods are stronger, as we always have.
To San Charbel the patron of the sick and needy I focus my attention.
I look to San Juditas the patron saint of lost causes.

column1: marian_santa_muerte_desc;This follower of the Sagrado Corazón is a Muerteño" — one of those devoted to la Santa Muerte, the Holy Death.

column2: This disciple of the Sagrado Corazón has a devotion to the patroness and mother of all Mexico, Our Lady of Guadalupe, who has been the most popular figure in the pantheon of el Sagrado Corazón since ancient times.

Among the most popular saints among the sagrado faithful San Charbel was a monk and a hermit of the faith from a land far across the sea whose countrymen brought the veneration of the saint to the land of mexico. Charbel was known even after death to have remained incorruptible and he is called upon by devotees to intercede on behalf of the sick and chapels dedicated to him are seeen throughput the land.

St. Jude the patron saint of lost causes, also known as San Judas Tadeo or San Juditas to his devotees, is one of the most popular saints to the sagrado faithful and is one of the original 12 apostles of Christ. Though beloved by all social classes San Juditas has a huge following among the poor to whom he is seen as a powerful protector and benefactor as well as a direct intercessor to Jesus Christ himself in his prayers.

Saint Paschal Baylón, known as San Pascual Bailón Yubero or just San Pascual, was an ancient franciscan monk that was elevated into sainthood after performing several miracles in life such as making water come out of a stone and multiplying bread for the poor. He has since become the patron saint of kitchens and "buen sazón", being specially venerated by cooks who pray to him for tasty food in exchange of a small dance.

Saint Innocence, also known as the Roman Virgin, was a Roman girl elevated to sainthood after being martyred by her own father when she converted to Christianity and had her first communion. Her remains were preserved inside a sculpted body in her semblance and have since become a holy relic. Her prayer is usually invoked for those wishing to make their faith as strong as hers.

El Alfa y Omega, Christ the King, it is the chosen form in which people who entrusted themselves to Jesucristo refer to Him. As He is the sole king of the world, rulers pray for Him so that his hand may guide their rule and the vulnerable pray to Him so that his sword may defend them from injustices, tyranny and evil.

Our Lady Star of the Sea is a title for La Virgen María often used by sailors, seafarers, and others that must face dangerous dangerous waters on a regular basis, not only guiding them through and protecting them as a star in the night sky, but by also being the guide towards Dios and Jesucristo themselves.

An ancient holy healer, El Santo Niño Fidencio, was given the power by Dios himself to channel El Espíritu Santo through his hands to cure all ailments of all those who visited him. His spirit was elevated to sainthood after his death, but he continued coming back to possess willing mediums so that they could better channel his powers. He is deeply revered by those that can be possessed by him and those with incurable diseases.

St. Michael, also known as San Miguel Arcángel, is the head of the angels that remained loyal to Dios, thus being made the protector of those that remain loyal to Him. La Biblia and Catholic tradition tells how time and time again when Satanás has attempted to subdue humanity, San Miguelito has come down from El Cielo to defeat evil in the name of Dios.
I will follow San Pascual the big fat Chef.
I  will follow Santa Inocencia, the protecter of the inocent.
I will follow Santo Niño Fidencio, the protector of the mystics.
I will follow Stella Maris, the protector of the sailors.
I will follow San César Chavez, the protector of the laborers.
I will follow Cristo Rey, the protector of the faithful.
I will follow San Miguelito, the protector of warriors.
Sometimes the dark ignorance of the world can be illuminated through instruction — other times it must come at the point of the sword
This character believes in a more personal, decentralized faith based on scripture alone, with roots in missionary work.
This character believes in the authority of the church hierarchy and in ancient traditions from Catholic heritage, like the veneration of Saints.
This character has been in the waters since birth, an auspicious sign for those who have reverence for the sea.

No one knows or even remembers why before the Event a bunch of women, all named Adela, began serving as warriors in the armies of great Caudillos. Nowadays a class of respected female warriors, called Adelitas, have become a revered part of Mexican martial tradition.

Named after the legendary armies of a Great Northern Mexican Caudillo of the times before the event, the Dorados are a group who serve the Mexican Benemérito as a sort of personal guard. Although their ranks are open to mostly cowboy foreign peoples, they also admit Northern Mexican vaquero cultures.

The leaders of the Mexican Empire have long claimed that their system of governance is a direct continuation of the administration of Old Mexico. While their claim is unverifiable, it is unquestionable that their system retains many of the qualities of centralized government that Old Mexico possessed. In this system, all land and water within imperial territory is originally owned by the crown, who has the right to transfer this ownership to particular. Hence, private property is a privilege created by the Emperor. This permits the Emperor to grant and revoke titles at will.

The Mexican Empire follows an ancient tradition of succession in which the Benemérito must secretly select his heir — known as the "Tapado" and then reveal him in a ceremony known as "el Destape." During the ceremony, the Benemérito points to his chosen successor and the most powerful individuals of the realm must decide whether to accept the charge or to defy his wishes and nominate their own candidate. Only commanders of the Empire, the Benemérito's council and immediate family are able to be selected as the "Tapado" and care should be taken in the selection — as the secrecy of the process is vital to the stability of the Empire. Should one discover who is to be the nextBenemérito, the cunning minds of the court of Mexico may be able to undermine the Empire with their ambitions.

Having it's origins in the reforms of Empress Fátima, Brazilian bureaucracy is a system that has a Monarch on the top, the lands underneath do not necessarily have one, and much of the power resides on the hands of a vast, complex group of officials, civil servants and courtiers, of which the most defining ones are the Governors and Captains, civil and military vassals respectively. Thus proper government lies in a carerful balance of power between the three main factions, the bureaucracy, the military and the Emperor himself.
Engage idolatrous "Christians" in holy war to eliminate heresy.

This chicahuaztli scepter is said to have been carved from a bone of Death herself, gifted to Humanity when she took pity on them and allowed them to return to the land of the living from the underworld. The scepter stands as a symbol of the covenant that must be followed to keep balance in the world and the benevolence of those spirits who must be venerated.

This codex is said to have been considered ancient even by the time of the event! In its ancient languages, it speaks of history and also of old gods who became the suns to protect the cycles of the world. We must not neglect them as they were in the past, lest the current cycle end and destroy the world once more.

Surely this headdress must have belonged to the legendary Motecuhzoma Xocoyotzin himself! The surviving stories of him are not well understood, but his wrath is said to be so great that his vengeance can still be felt long after his death.

This intimidating-looking instrument produces a tone that sounds eerily similar to a person screaming in pain. Anceint indigenous Mexicans once used them on the field of battle to intimidate their foes and now they serve the same purpose in our armies.

The Sash is a symbol of Mexican Imperial authority and continuity. Expertly Crafted out of Quetzal, Macaw, and Heron feathers, the resplendent sash serves as the Mexican Regalia and illustrates the majesty of the Empire.
The Image of Our Lady of Guadalupe

This most venerable image of the Virgin of Guadalupe was imprinted in the tilma of Juan Diego Cuauhtlatoatzin more than a thousand years ago by the Virgin Mary herself. Surviving every calamity to have befallen her children, the mother of all Mexicans continues to serve as the most enduring symbol of Mexico and its sanctity. \n§Y*§!Mexican religions gain a Moral Authority bonus when this artifact is held by its head of faith.

According to legend, this bell rang clear when the very idea of Mexico was conceived. Flanked by ornate cherubs and with the names of legendary heroic figures of ancient times carved in it, this resplendent brass bell exudes an aura of patriotic mysticism, and when it chimes everyone hears: "Mexicans, at the cry of war!".

Meticulously preserved for countless generations, legends say this prosthetic leg once belonged to a tyrant king who had made war in the lands of the Lone Star. Now it adorns a wall as a conversation piece and ocasionally serves as the club of choice when recieving the ceremonial first pitch of a strike-ball game.

This ancient Golden lance adorned with scenes of long lost myths and legends. Said to have been a weapon of an unlikely hero who slayed a Texan Goliath from elder days before the event, the the artifact was thought to have been lost to history until it came into the possession of the house of Paleo.
These ancient ruins contain the bones of the most revered ancestors from time immemorial. Only the most bold rulers can hope to have theirs added to this sacred place.

The ancient Castle of Chapultepec sits at the top of a hill overlooking the great avenue from which comes tribute from all over Mexico. It has long been the seat of government and a symbol of the enduring power of the Mexican Empire.

It is believed that death herself dwells in the halls of these red-domed buildings, interpreted by the seers that reside within this holy place. Some say that in the crypts under the structures," the seers can interpret the exact date of one's death using the Column of Life — the cosmic axis of the world itself.
This fortress on a hill protects the holy city from the threat of enemy invasion.
Dogs serve as the companions of the dead, helping them over treacherous rivers on the years-long pilgrimage of death — provided that they are given the honor they deserve in life...

Known by countless names since time immemorial, the sacred fire, the oldest and origin of all things, protects and guides the deceased on their way to the afterlife. This flame is continuously maintained as a sacred representation of this covenant.
Exotic creatures and strange beasts are brought from all over the expansive territory of what was once Old Mexico to be exhibited in the Chapultepec Zoo.

Deep inside Chapultepec Forrest lies the entrance to a cave — an entrance to the underworld — that is said to have been used by Moctezuma himself to enter Mictlán. Some even whisper of secret passages and lost treasures within...
Only the best and the brightest children of the Mexican aristocracy can hope to enter the Heroic Military College and bring honor to the legacy of the Niños Heroes.

The water of the lakes surrounding the Grand Metropoli of Mexico is brackish and unfit for human consumption. The aqueduct of Chapultepec is a necessary component of the city and a symbol of the Empire's patronage of the people.

None can say exactly how many priceless documents were lost from the archive in the Event, but perhaps with some... creative license, the people can be reminded of how our people directly descend from greatness.
The castle needs its own honor guard to protect the priceless artifacts — and people — who reside within it.
A beautiful mural portraying the ancient history and ancestors of our people — fact or fiction, who can really say for certain?
Call forth a band of devoted worshipers from the peasantry to help reinforce our forces.
This character has recently called upon a fanatic group of peasants.
Reorganize the Lamanita Faith for all ages.
Sanctify thyself through an act to mortify your sins.
Has not recently partaken in mortification of the flesh
Adopt a system of Brazilian Bureaucracy which has one August Emperor ruling over multiple vassals in a system of regulations and bureaucracy.
All titles besides your primary one shall be forfeit

For a long time the faithful awaited for the return of the Pontifex Maximus. Your current position has led many among clergy to see you as the restored Pontifex yourself. Now, it's only up to you to recognize the claim yourself.
Send money to aid in the cause of Justo Armas
Send soldiers to aid in the cause of Justo Armas
Swear the Prelate’s oath of fealty
Join Justo Armas' war as an ally and be vassalized by him if he wins the war
Hasn't taken a war preparation decision in the last 4 months
Recruit a Dorado commander into the Benemérito's court
Los Dorados army will be increased by 10% of their base size
Will receive a new army of conscripts in your capital
Create the Rite of the Navegantes
The fisher-folk of the Mar de Cortés could be brought into the fold of the Sacred Heart if we respect their traditions and allow them to keep certain rites...
Create the Rite of the Fidencistas
The espiritists of the cult of el Niño Fidencio could be brought into the fold of the Sacred Heart if we respect their traditions and allow them to keep certain rites...
Create the Rite of the Cristeros
The faithful numeraries of the Prelature of Cristo Rey could be brought into the fold of the Sacred Heart if we respect their traditions and allow them to keep certain organizational independence...

The agile light cavalry of the old Mexican tradition are raised here. These gallant horsemen are masters of the saddle, full of daring and bravado. When they aren't skirmishing and harrassing the enemy in battle, they can be found in the many equestrian competitions of the charrería

Trained here are he archers of the Purépechas who are said to be so skilled as to be able to fell a hummingbird in flight with a single arrow. The prestigious bowmen are respected among the Purépechas and are rarely seen without their bow — measuring the size of a man — at their side.
Moravians may change their religious branch once per lifetime.

The Unitas fratrum faith is split into two main theological groups the pastorals who focus on personal faith and the authority of the scriptures while maintaing a decentralized church structure focused on local communities and the parochials who focus on the traditions and theology of the universal church held by such saints as San Oscar Romero and on a hierarchical church structure.
Focus on personal faith and decentralized authority.
Focus on tradition and the church heirarchy.
With your hefty knowledge of all things, you can choose to delve into the more esoteric aspects of faith.

After the lighting of incense and a night of intense, monotonous prayer, you have begun your journey into the esoteric, into the realm of the greatest saints and preachers. As the sweat pours down your face, you feel a warm, gracious presence.
Señor Jesucristo, Hijo de Dios, ten piedad de mí...

At last the Great Schism between the Cristeros and the Sacred Heart faithful has been mended. After his victory near Toluca in 2541, Benemérito Wenceslao el Tizón elevated the Missionaries of the Sacred Heart to the state church after being visited by the Virgin of Guadalupe. The power of the Prelature was broken and the faith schismed, the followers of the Sacred Heart taking it upon themselves to venerate folk saints and idols. With the Benemérito of the Empire now being a Cristero the reunification of the two sister churches can now begin.

In the centuries since the Event there have always been realms, petty kings and upstart warlords that claimed to be the successors to some ancient now dead empire, but none could claim to be an ancient empire that had survived the Event, no one but the empire of México City. La República is the continuation of that ancient state and although it grew to powerful heights in the past, centuries of mismanagement, rebellions and religious strife led to its fracturing and almost annihilation. \n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has finally quashed the beliefs that La República may collapse, [Root.GetSubjectPronounCap] has absorbed the realms of the caudillos back into the fold and has ushered in a new era of Peace, Order and Progress not seen since the times of Benemérito Julián de Jesús Jacaranda. \nAlthough Old México is still not whole again and the struggle for unity will continue, one thing is certain - The Mexican Eagle is back.

La República is the continuation of that ancient state and although it grew to powerful heights in the past, centuries of mismanagement, rebellions and religious strife led to its fracturing and almost annihilation. \n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has finally quashed the beliefs that La República may collapse, [Root.GetSubjectPronounCap] has absorbed the realms of the caudillos back into the fold and has ushered in a new era of Peace, Order and Progress not seen since the times of Benemérito Julián de Jesús Jacaranda. \nAlthough Old México is still not whole again and the struggle for unity will continue, one thing is certain - The Mexican Eagle is back.

Even after the restoration of the Empire many years ago, many still failed to believe that the Ancient Empire of México City had enough power to fully restore the borders they used to have before the Event, those who had doubted have been silenced for good. \n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has succeeded where even Benemérito Julián de Jesús Jacaranda and all the other Beneméritos of the Jacaranda Dynasty had failed, [Root.GetSubjectPronounCap] has absorbed all realms within Old México back into the fold and brought to the land a new era of Union, Religion and Independence. \nLa República’s old borders have finally been restored, but the stories tell that Old México used to be Greater México - the Great Mexican Eagle is not done yet.

Even after the restoration of the Empire many years ago, many still failed to believe that the Ancient Empire of México City had enough power to fully restore the borders they used to have before the Event, those who had doubted have been silenced for good. \n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has succeeded where the not even the Emperors of the Triple Alliance could not prosper, [Root.GetSubjectPronounCap] has absorbed all realms within Old México back into the fold and brought to the land a new era of Union, Religion and Independence. \nOnce more a tyrannical empire extends its tentacles out of México City and into the land. We have resisted for over a thousand years, and we shall continue to do so!

column3: Even after the restoration of the Empire many years ago, many still failed to believe that the Ancient Empire of México City had enough power to fully restore the borders they used to have before the Event, those who had doubted have been silenced for good. \n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] has succeeded where even Benemérito Julián de Jesús Jacaranda and all the other Beneméritos of the Jacaranda Dynasty had failed, [Root.GetSubjectPronounCap] has absorbed all realms within Old México back into the fold and brought to the land a new era of Union, Religion and Independence. \nLet us hope the eagle doesn’t not venture into our vicinity.

column2: This child in my court is falling for the traps of a wayward and foul school of thought or just lacks any religious consideration at all. I will show them the light.

For too long has the faith been splintered by the bickering of those who were not willing to give up their special privileges and submit to the rightful authority of El Arzobispado de México, rightful head of the church under the protection of La República. Those days are now over and the (adjective for Sagrado Corazón faithful) rejoice as not only the faith is restored, but also the realm, with the official incorporations of Jalisco and El Bajío into La República after finally reclaiming the totality of their territory. The Cristeros have been granted tolerance and they won't need to abandon their ways of veneration, as long as they also tolerate those that El Arzobispo deems non-heretical. No longer will the shouts of "Viva Cristo Rey!" strike fear in the hearts of the (faithful of the Sagrado Corazón), but rather be a warm reminder that Jesucristo is the true lord of us all.

Even since before the Event, there has been a stigma from the wider Mexican population to those that venerated the folk saint Niño Fidencio, that should end today. El Arzobispado de México has now decreed the beatification of El Santo Niño Fidencio and extending protections to the Fidencista Church and their unique rituals as long as they acknowledge the supremacy of El Arzobispo and that El Santo Niño Fidencio is only a saint, not a new prophet. El Arzobispo thanked Benemérito (INSERT NAME) for making this absorption of Fidencismo possible after finally reconquering the former states of Chihuahua and Durango. Sagrado Corazón priests now journey to Espinazo to study the Cajitas and the rituals with muddy water.

Navegantes, the strange faith that arose in the shores of the Sea of Cortés, they had always been far away from the influence of Mexico proper, even if it was a territory of Old Mexico. After the conquest of the baja California Peninsula by La República, the Benemérito and Arzobispo both quietly pondered how they could absorb the Jonás Priesthood into the Sagrado Corazón Church. After a brief council it has been decided that the Church of the Navegantes will become subordinate to El Arzobispado de México, in exchange for this the Navegantes will no longer be able to continue their rituals with their co-religionaries but must direct their fury to infidels.
died in an accident during a re-enactment of Jesus Christ's crucifixion
